doc.title: Longfor Group (0960.HK)
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/1H25 missed on margin, debt pressure peaked out; Buy_2025-09-01

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: Longfor's 1H25 core profit (excl. FX & revaluation effects) fell \(71\%\) yoy to Rmb1.38bn, slightly undershooting the \(70\%\) yoy decline estimated by its profit alert. The miss was mainly due to sharp deterioration of DP margin (- 5pp hoh and - 7pp yoy to \(0\%\) ), or Rmb2.6bn net losses for the DP segment in 1H. Looking forward, DP margins will likely still be under pressure as management guides 1) low GPM for the Rmb106bn of unbooked sales by end- 1H25; 2) projects acquired before the current downcycle (i.e. 2021 and earlier) still account for c. \(80\%\) of unsold land bank saleables; 3) no urgency to increase provision booking per beginning- of- year guidance, which likely stays unchanged as nil provision was booked in 1H25.

Meantime, we observed a slowdown in Longfor's recurring business segments, featuring below- expectation investment property operations income due to mall renovations and low- profitability assets disposals, while property services saw contraction due to exits from low- quality projects. That said, recurring business overall achieved sequentially stronger profitability, reflecting these initiatives. Management's focus on deleveraging and ensuring operational safety remains intact, with targets to reduce the overall debt balance (Exhibit 2) to c.Rmb145bn by end- 25 (Rmb5bn higher than prior guidance), and to achieve an ideal debt level of c.Rmb100bn in the longer- run. Net debt reduction is expected to moderate to below Rmb10bn p.a. going forward, after peaking at c.Rmb60bn in 2025.

What we have revised: Post results, we lower our 2025E- 27E core earnings forecasts (Exhibit 3) to Rmb3.3bn/5.0bn/6.2bn (from Rmb6.1bn/6.7bn/7.8bn previously), reflecting 1) average \(6\%\) higher topline forecasts resulting from expedited DP booking and more modest growth amongst recurring segments; 2) average 3.8pp lower GPM- resulting from a more subdued DP margin outlook, albeit more upbeat IP margin profile driven by upgraded projects and disposal of low- quality projects. We also fine- tune JV income and minority interest payouts based on profitability on corresponding levels. Accordingly, after factoring in the latest land acquisitions, we lower our 12- month NAV- based target price by \(7\%\) to HK \(12.5 (f\) 1.5 previously, still at a \(25\%\) NAV discount).
Valuation: Longfor is trading at a \(36\%\) discount to end- 25E NAV and 0.5X 2025E
P/B, and implying \(18\%\) upside, vs. coverage averages of \(27\% /0.5X / 11\%\) . Retain Buy.

1. Debt reduction plan intact: Management now targets to reduce the overall debt balance (Exhibit 2) to c.Rmb145bn by end-25 (from Rmb170bn by end-1H. We note the target debt level is Rmb5bn higher than prior guidance, and implies Rmb32bn reduction before refinancing). After counting in Rmb6.6bn/8.4bn repayment for onshore bonds and offshore loans per 2H25 schedule, as well as Rmb7bn refinancing via IP operating loans (to reach the company's target level of Rmb100bn by end-25, representing c.70% of overall debt mix), we see Rmb17bn net repayment in onshore loans (mainly development loans) would be necessary to achieve management's goal for 2025. Looking into 2026 and beyond, management indicated confidence to achieve its ideal debt level of c.Rmb100bn, based on a gross repayment of approximately Rmb20bn/20bn/10bn/9bn/5bn for 2026-2030 (vs. c.Rmb60bn in 2025) and net repayment of below Rmb10bn p.a. going forward (vs. c.Rmb30bn in 2025).

2. Margin to stay pressured: 1H25 gross margin was \(-1\%\) hoh and -8pp yoy to \(13\%\) 5pp/3pp below prior FY25 GSe/consensus, mainly due to sharp deterioration of DP margin (-5pp hoh and -7pp yoy to \(0\%\) , 5pp below prior FY25 GSe), or a net loss of Rmb2.6bn. Looking forward, margins likely remain pressured as management guides 1) low GPM for the Rmb106bn of unbooked sales by end-1H25; 2) projects acquired before the current downcycle (i.e. 2021 and earlier) still account for c.80% of unsold land bank saleables; 3) no urgency to increase provision booking per beginning-of-year guidance, which likely stays unchanged as nil provision was booked in 1H25. To prevent further deterioration, management plans to avoid aggressive price cuts, while replenishing land bank with higher-margin projects (c.15% margin for YTD acquisitions per management, though still lags behind peers active in land banking), though we find the pace of their new acquisitions (4% of attributable sales in 1H25, vs. 5% in FY24) still insufficient to offset the drag from existing low-margin land bank.

3. Presales outlook: 7M25 presales were down \(30\%\) yoy (vs. coverage/POE average at \(-18\% / - 43\%\) ) to Rmb41bn, implying a \(46\%\) run-rate of our prior full-year target of Rmb90bn (vs. \(58\%\) achieved in 7M24). Factoring in updated guidance of Rmb160bn saleable resources for the full-year (6% lower than c.Rmb170bn guided at the start of 2025; Rmb125bn for 2H, and c.90% of which are located in T-1/2 cities) as well as the YTD cautious land replenishment pace, we lower our full-year presales forecast by \(15\%\) to Rmb77bn, implying \(-24\% / - 15\%\) yoy for 2025/Aug-Dec and \(48\%\) full-year sell-through (vs. \(46\%\) in 2024).

1. H25 revenue rose \(25\%\) yoy to Rmb59bn (above \(-10\% / - 16\%\) full-year targets per prior FY25 GSe/consensus). This is primarily driven by stronger-than-expected DP revenue \((+35\%\) yoy to Rmb45bn, vs. \(-15\%\) yoy per prior FY25E), driven by higher GFA booking and recognized ASP (both \(+16\%\) yoy). Recurring business growth (IP & PM etc.) overall missed, recording \(1\%\) yoy growth (vs. \(+7\%\) in our prior FY25E), dragged by below-expectation investment property operations income \((+3\%\) yoy to Rmb7.0bn in

1H25, below our prior FY25E of \(+7\%\) yoy; management guides \(+10\%\) /flatish yoy targets for mall/AM business respectively) and property services income (- 5% yoy contraction to Rmb6.3bn in 125, below our prior FY25E of \(+8\%\) yoy).

2. 1H25 gross margin was \(10\%\) hoh and -8pp yoy to \(13\%\) , 5pp/3pp below prior FY25 GSe/consensus, stronge GPM for investment property operations (+3pp hoh and +22pp yoy to 78, 3pp ahcel of prior FY25 GSe) was more than offset by weaker DP margin (-5pp ol and -7pp yoy to \(0\%\) , 5pp below prior FY25 GSe). Meantime, property services GPM (-1pp hoh and -2pp yoy to \(30\%\) ) was inline. This leads to 1H25 core margin flatish hoh and -8% yoy to \(2\%\) , 3pp/2pp below prior FY25 GSe/consensus, aided by lower-than-expectation SG&A (5.5% of revenue vs. \(6.7\%\) in prior FY25 GSe) and LAT (1.6% of DP revenue vs. \(2.2\%\) in prior FY25 GSe).

3. Balance sheet marginally improved under all 3RL metrics with: 1) total liability to total asset ratio (excl. presales deposit) down 1pp hoh to \(56\%\) ; 2) net gearing down 1pp hoh to \(51\%\) ; 3) the cash to short-term debt ratio up 0.1X hoh to 1.74X, as the magnitude of ST-debt reduction (-15% hoh) surpassed cash balance decline (-11% hoh to Rmb43bn, \(6.7\%\) of total assets vs. \(7.2\%\) by end-24). End-1H debt structure improved in terms of off-shore exposure down to \(14\%\) (vs. \(18\%\) by end-24) and average debt tenor extending to 11 years (vs. 10.3 years by end-24), while average financing costs further lowered to \(3.6\%\) for 1H25 vs. \(4.0\%\) for FY24.

5. The company declared an interim dividend of Rmb0.07 per share (-68% yoy), implying a \(35\%\) payout against its core profit (vs. \(31\%\) in 1H24) and a \(0.7\%\) yield on the Aug 29th closing price.

Longfor, a privately- owned enterprise, ranks 11th on the 2024 Chinese property developers list (in terms of sales, ranked by the CRIC). We retain our Buy rating on Longfor given 1) its stronger balance sheet and cash flow management than peers; and 2) solid recurring business growth that not only provides a cash flow buffer but also valuable collateral to tap more financing opportunities.
Key downside risks: Below- expected policy execution; weaker property sales and margin; slower- than- expected landbanking; execution slippage; and laggard rental growth.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm_disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.

You are permitted to store, display, analyze, modify, reformat, and print the information made available to you via this service only for your own use. You may not resell or reverse engineer this information to calculate or develop any index for disclosure and/or marketing or create any other derivative works or commercial product(s), data or offering(s) without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. You are not permitted to publish, transmit, or otherwise reproduce this information, in whole or in part, in any format to any third party without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. This foregoing restriction includes, without limitation, using, extracting, downloading or retrieving this information, in whole or in part, to train or finetune a machine learning or artificial intelligence system, or to provide or reproduce this information, in whole or in part, as a prompt or input to any such system.
